title: 3 economists share Nobel Prize for ‘experimental approach’ to solving poverty
text:
The 2019 Nobel Prize for economics was awarded Monday to Abhijit Banerjee, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Esther Duflo, who also teaches at MIT; and Michael Kremer, an economist at Harvard University. (Henrik Montgomery/AP)

Three economists were awarded the Nobel Prize in economics on Monday morning for their “experimental approach” to solving global poverty.

The winners are Abhijit Banerjee, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Esther Duflo, who also teaches at MIT; and Michael Kremer, an economist at Harvard University.

“In just two decades their new experiment-based approach has transformed development economics, which is now a flourishing field of research,” the Nobel Prize committee said on Twitter.

The Nobel committee credits the researchers with breaking down large questions about poverty into smaller research questions, such as the best interventions for improving child health, and using field experiments to solve them.
description: The prize was awarded to Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo of MIT, and Michael Kremer, an economist at Harvard University.
